verses.text: Now all the tax collectors and sinners were coming near to hear him.
verses.comment: Jesus welcomes those considered outcasts by society, showing his mission is to save all, regardless of social status or perceived sinfulness.

verses.text: And both the Pharisees and the scribes were grumbling, saying, "This man receives sinners and eats with them."
verses.comment: Religious leaders criticise Jesus’ association with sinners. This exemplifies the radical inclusivity of God’s grace and how Jesus, by sharing meals, points to reconciliation and communion with God.

verses.text: And he told them this parable, saying:
verses.comment: Jesus uses parables to reveal divine mysteries in simple stories, inviting all listeners to deeper understanding.

verses.text: “Which of you, having a hundred sheep, if he has lost one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine in the open field and go after the one that is lost until he finds it?”
verses.comment: The shepherd’s devotion to a single lost sheep illustrates God’s personal care for each individual, echoing Old Testament imagery of God as shepherd.

verses.text: And when he has found it, he lays it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
verses.comment: The image of carrying the lost sheep affirms God’s joy in redemption, a foreshadowing of Christ bearing burdens for the lost.

verses.text: And when he comes home, he calls together his friends and neighbors, saying to them, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep that was lost.’
verses.comment: The communal celebration reflects the heavenly rejoicing over one sinner who repents. It also hints at the importance of Christian community sharing in God's joy.

verses.text: I tell you, in the same way, there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous who have no need of repentance.
verses.comment: Jesus reveals the heavenly perspective on repentance, emphasising mercy and the value placed on those returning to God. Implies the necessity of confession and reconciliation.

verses.text: Or what woman, if she has ten silver coins and loses one coin, does not light a lamp, sweep the house, and search diligently until she finds it?
verses.comment: The lamp symbolises spiritual illumination, while searching persistently mirrors God’s unfailing pursuit of each soul.

verses.text: And when she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, ‘Rejoice with me, because I have found the coin that I lost.’
verses.comment: The celebration underscores the profound joy God and the faithful share when one lost soul returns.

verses.text: In the same way, I tell you, there is joy before the angels of God over one sinner who repents.”
verses.comment: Heavenly beings rejoice at repentance, suggesting the close connection between earthly actions and heavenly reality.

verses.text: And he said, “A certain man had two sons.
verses.comment: The following parable, often termed the Prodigal Son, explores reconciliation, inheritance, and mercy.

verses.text: The younger of them said to his father, ‘Father, give me the share of the property that is coming to me.’ And so he divided his property between them.
verses.comment: The request signifies estrangement and self-reliance; the father’s granting portrays unconditional generosity.

verses.text: Not many days later, the younger son gathered all he had and traveled to a distant country, and there he spent his wealth in reckless living.
verses.comment: The ‘distant country’ parallels separation from God; squandered wealth alludes to spiritual poverty.

verses.text: After he had spent everything, a severe famine came upon that land, and he began to be in need.
verses.comment: Physical famine echoes spiritual hunger resulting from separation from God.

verses.text: So he went and hired himself out to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him into his fields to feed pigs.
verses.comment: Feeding pigs shows the son’s degradation, especially for Jews for whom swine were ritually unclean.

verses.text: He was longing to fill his stomach with the pods that the pigs were eating, but no one gave him anything.
verses.comment: His hunger signals spiritual emptiness—a consequence of turning away from his father.

verses.text: But when he came to his senses, he said, ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have food to spare, and here I am starving to death!’
verses.comment: Awareness of his condition prompts repentance, laying the foundation for mercy to operate.

verses.text: I will get up and go to my father and say to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.’
verses.comment: True repentance involves acknowledging wrong before both God and men.

verses.text: ‘I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Make me like one of your hired servants.’
verses.comment: Humility is central to reconciliation; the son’s willingness to accept servanthood reveals contrition.

verses.text: And he got up and went to his father. But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was moved with compassion; he ran and embraced his son and kissed him.
verses.comment: God’s compassion is active, seeking the repentant before they arrive—highlighting the initiative of divine mercy.

verses.text: The son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’
verses.comment: Confession of guilt is integral to reconciliation. The repetition shows the sincerity of repentance.

verses.text: But the father said to his servants, ‘Quickly bring out the best robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his hand and sandals on his feet.’
verses.comment: Restoration to sonship is immediate. Robe, ring, and sandals represent forgiveness, authority, and dignity—images of grace dispensed sacramentally.

verses.text: And bring the fattened calf and kill it. Let us eat and celebrate.
verses.comment: Feasting symbolizes the joy of restoration and hints at the heavenly banquet prepared for the redeemed.

verses.text: 'For this son of mine was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.' And they began to celebrate.
verses.comment: The father’s words echo the theme of resurrection and new life, fulfilled spiritually in Christian conversion.

verses.text: Now his older son was in the field, and as he came and approached the house, he heard music and dancing.
verses.comment: The older son’s arrival introduces the tension of self-righteousness and the challenge of accepting grace given to others.

verses.text: So he called one of the servants and asked what these things meant.
verses.comment: Inquiry into celebration signifies confusion or lack of understanding regarding God’s mercy.

verses.text: And he said to him, ‘Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has received him back safe and sound.’
verses.comment: Emphasis on restoration and safety signifies completeness in reconciliation.

verses.text: But he was angry and refused to go in. So his father came out and pleaded with him.
verses.comment: The older son’s resentment mirrors Jonah’s; the father’s invitation reflects God’s persistent call for unity and humility.

verses.text: But he answered his father, ‘Look, for many years I have served you and never disobeyed your command, yet you never gave me a young goat, so I could celebrate with my friends.’
verses.comment: The complaint reveals a transactional view of sonship, challenging readers to see reward as rooted in relationship and grace, not merit alone.

verses.text: But when this son of yours came, who has consumed your wealth with prostitutes, you killed the fattened calf for him!’
verses.comment: The older son's language distances himself from his brother, contrasting his perceived righteousness with his brother's sinfulness.

verses.text: And he said to him, ‘Son, you are always with me, and all that I have is yours.’
verses.comment: The father's assurance reveals that fidelity is always honoured and participation in grace is open, hinting at deeper inheritance and unity through remaining in God’s presence.

verses.text: ‘But we had to celebrate and be glad, because your brother was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’”
verses.comment: Concludes with the central motif: restoration, resurrection, and the necessity of joyful celebration. Points to the communal and liturgical nature of Christian rejoicing in renewed life.
